Rafael Chaves Souto Araújo

Bolsista de Produtividade em Pesquisa do CNPq - Nível 2

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/1509277905143351
  • Última atualização do currículo em 18/09/2019

Possui graduação em Física Bacharelado pela Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (2004), mestrado em Física pelo Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Físicas (2006) e doutorado pela Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (2010). Trabalhou como pesquisador pós-doutor no Institute for Photonic Sciences de Barcelona e nos institutos de física das Universidades de Freiburg e Colônia. Atualmente é líder do grupo de pesquisa em Informação Quântica (www.iip.ufrn.br/qiqm) do Instituto Internacional de Física (IIP-UFRN) em Natal. Em 2018 foi selecionado como grantee do Instituto Serrapilheira. É também professor da Escola de Ciências e Tecnologia (ECT-UFRN) e professor permanente da pós-graduação do Departamento de Física da UFRN. Tem experiência na área de física e aprendizagem de máquina, com ênfase em computacão e informacão quântica, atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas: emaranhamento, não-localidade quântica, sistemas quânticos abertos, prcessamento quântico de informação, criptografia quântica, fundamentos de mecânica quântica, implementações experimentais, inteligência artificial, modelos causais. (Texto informado pelo autor)

9.
Quantum correlations and device-independent quantum information processing
Objetivo: As proved by Bell in 1964 in his seminal theorem, quantum correlations are incompatible with a description in terms of local hidden variable (LHV) models. The origin of Bell'™s result can be traced back to another milestone in the conceptual development of quantum mechanics, the EPR paper where a thought experiment is proposed to prove the apparent incompleteness of quantum mechanics, which then would emerge as an œeffective theory of an underlying LHV model. It was not until Bell's theorem that the EPR thought experiment could be put into an experimentally testable ground. Bell observed that even absent of any detailed information about the physical processes involved ? an approach known nowadays as device-independent ? the EPR assumptions alone imply experimentally testable constraints on the correlations that can arise from any local realistic description of nature. These constraints are the famous Bell inequalities, which are violated by quantum correlations, the phenomenon known as quantum nonlocality. In our group we investigate generalizations of Bell's theorem to a broad variety of relevant scenarios, also trying to understand how to use these non-classical correlations as physical resource in device-independent applications ranging from universal quantum computation to quantum cryptography, randomness generation and efficient distributed computing over complex networks ..
10.
Open Quantum Systems
Objetivo: The development of quantum information theory has established, beyond doubt, the fact that quantum mechanical systems allow for a wide variety of new possibilities in the processing of information. However, under realistic situations where actual applications take place, systems are unavoidably subject to noise and other uncontrollable source of errors. In our group we are interested in characterizing and probing the resilience of quantum resources in the presence of noise and in particular to develop ways to circumvent its deleterious effects. This research thread include topic as entanglement and non-locality dynamics, quantum metrology in the presence of noise and quantum control..
11.
Causal Modeling
Objetivo: It is a relatively new insight of classical statistics that empirical data can contain information about causation rather than mere correlation. Since its development in the mid-90s, causal inference has found applications in the most diverse fields and more recently has been proven to provide a powerful framework for revisiting and generalizing many of the cornerstones of quantum theory. Yet, the connection between the mathematical theory of causality and problems in quantum information remains in its infancy, offering a largely unexplored territory for both fundamental and applied research. In our group we develop the conceptual and mathematical tools required for a proper understanding of the role of causality in quantum mechanics but at the same time also providing new insights and techniques to the classical theory of causal inference. From a fundamental perspective, our aim is to understand non-classical behavior from a causal perspective, including question such as: Which causal structures yield quantum correlations without a classical analogue? What are the new forms of non-classicality they give rise to? From the practical side, we are interested in developing new applications, from experimentally less demanding cryptographic protocols to more efficient ways to communicate within complex quantum networks..
12.
Machine learning for quantum information problems
Objetivo: With far reaching applications, in the last years machine learning tools started to routinely be used in physics problems, from the filtering of astrophysical and cosmological data to the understanding of phase transitions in many-body systems. In the quantum information context most research has been focused on the opposite problem, that is, how quantum machine learning algorithms could enhance our information processing abilities. Thus, the natural question remains: Can we use classical (already available) machine learning techniques to solve hard quantum information problems? We employ modern machine learning algorithms (such as deep learning) to characterize diverse classical and quantum causal networks. Our focus is analysis of causal structures involving several latent variables (as the entanglement swapping network). In another thread, we use machine learning (both supervised and unsupervised algorithms) to characterize many-body systems and quantum phase transitions.
Grande área: Ciências Exatas e da Terra
Grande Área: Ciências Exatas e da Terra / Área: Física / Subárea: Computacão e Informacão Quântica.
Palavras-chave: Aprendizagem de máquina; Emaranhamento; Causal Inference; Quantum Mechanics.
13.
Experimental implementations
Objetivo: A characteristic feature of quantum information is the fact that theory and experiment work very closely.We work in close collaboration with many experimental groups around the world, be it testing fundamental concepts or implementing protocols with potential technological impact. Of particular relevance are the proof of principle implementations of complex quantum networks giving rise to new forms of quantum correlations. The main physical platform to be used in our experimental investigations is based on photonic technology. The main ingredient is the generation of entangled states using different degrees of freedom. We consider experimental setups generating entanglement in i) polarization, ii) orbital angular momentum (OAM) and iii) spatial modes. Each of these offers different advantages and limitations..
Grande área: Ciências Exatas e da Terra
Palavras-chave: Nonlocality; quantum contextuality; Quantum Mechanics; Causal Inference; Emaranhamento.
